title: Analysis of multistate hierarchical outcomes by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: vignette demonstrates use R-package rmt restricted-mean-time--favor--treatment approach analysis multiple prioritized outcomes.

title: Analysis of multistate hierarchical outcomes by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: recap methodology, formulate patient experience multiple events multistate process Y(t) taking values ordered set \{0,1,\ldots, K, K+1\}, larger integer representing series condition. example, Y(t)=0 cancer patient state remission, Y(t)=1 cancer relapsed, Y(t)=2 metastasized, Y(t)=3 patient died. methodology rmt sufficiently general applicable wide range settings, long following assumptions met: outcome process progressive (can transition less serious serious state), .e., Y(t)\leq Y(s) t\leq s; Death absorbing state, .e., competing risks death (hence “cure models” allowed).

title: Analysis of multistate hierarchical outcomes by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: Let Y^{()} denote outcome process group (=1 treatment =0 control). estimand interest constructed generalized pairwise comparison framework (Buyse, 2010). Y^{(1)}\perp Y^{(0)}, let \mu(\tau)=E\int_0^\tau \{Y^{(1)}(t)< Y^{(0)}(t)\}{\rm d}t - E\int_0^\tau \{Y^{(1)}(t)> Y^{(0)}(t)\}{\rm d}t, pre-specified follow-time \tau. call \mu(\tau) restricted mean time (RMT) favor treatment interpret average time gained treatment favorable condition. generalizes familiar restricted mean survival time account intermediate stages disease progression. fact, can shown \mu(\tau) reduces net restricted mean survival time (Royston & Parmar, 2011) two-state life-death model. details methodology, refer Mao (2021). overall effect size can decomposed stage-wise components: \mu(\tau)=\sum_{k=1}^{K+1}\mu_k(\tau) \begin{equation}\label{eq:comp}\tag{*} \mu_k(\tau)=E\int_0^\tau \{Y^{(1)}(t)<k, Y^{(0)}(t)=k\}{\rm d}t - E\int_0^\tau \{Y^{(0)}(t)<k, Y^{(1)}(t)=k\}{\rm d}t. \end{equation} component \mu_k(\tau) can interpreted average ``pre-state k’’ time gained treatment among transitioned state (k+1) higher. clear last component \mu_{K+1}(t) always stands usual net restricted mean survival time.

title: Analysis of multistate hierarchical outcomes by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: main data-fitting function rmtfit(). use function, input data must organized “long” format. Specifically, need id variable containing unique patient identifiers, time variable containing times transitioning events, status variable labeling event type (status=k transitioning state k status=0 censored; note death represented status=K+1), , finally, binary trt variable containing subject-level treatment arm indicators. id, time, status, trt variables data frame data, can use formula form function: Otherwise, can feed vector-valued variables directly function: (default) type option specifies input multistate data rather recurrent event data (type=="recurrent"). returned object obj contains basically information overall stage-wise RMTs. extract relevant information particular \tau=tau, use

title: Analysis of multistate hierarchical outcomes by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: plot estimated \mu(\tau) function \tau, use option conf=T requests 95% confidence limits overlaid. color line type confidence limits can controlled arguments conf.col conf.lty, respectively. graphical parameters can specified , , passed underlying generic plot method.

title: Analysis of multistate hierarchical outcomes by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: dynamic profile treatment effects follow-progresses captured bouquet plot, puts \tau vertical axis plots stage-wise restricted mean win/loss times, .e., first second terms right hand side (*), functions \tau two sides. bouquet plot useful visualizes component-wise contributions overall effect. plot , use graphical parameters can specified , , passed underlying generic plot method.

previous_headings: AN EXAMPLE WITH A COLON CANCER TRIAL
title: Analysis of multistate hierarchical outcomes by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: landmark colon cancer trial efficacy levamisole fluorouracil reported Moertel et al. (1990). trial recruited 929 patients stage C disease randomly assigned levamisole treatment alone, levamisole combined fluorouracil, control. focus comparison combined treatment control groups, consisting 304 314 patients, respectively. endpoints interest cancer relapse death. death rates treatment control groups 40% 53%, relapse rates 39% 56%, median follow-times 5.7 5.1 years, respectively. dataset colon_lev (subset colon dataset survival package) contained rmt package can loaded dataset already format suitable rmtfit() (status= 1 relapse = 2 death).

previous_headings: AN EXAMPLE WITH A COLON CANCER TRIAL
title: Analysis of multistate hierarchical outcomes by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: first fit data output, conclude , 7.5 years, combined treatment average gains patient 0.97 extra year favorable state compared control. total effect size comprises additional 0.62 year survival time 0.35 year relapse-free time among survivors. matrix containing inferential results can obtained summary(obj,tau=7.5)$tab.
code: obj=rmtfit(ms(id,time,status)~rx,data=colon_lev) ## print the event numbers by group obj #> Call: #> rmtfit.formula(formula = ms(id, time, status) ~ rx, data = colon_lev) #>  #>           N State 1 Death Med follow-up time #> Control 315     177   168           5.081451 #> Lev+5FU 304     119   123           5.749487  # summarize the inference results for tau=7.5 years summary(obj,tau=7.5) #> Call: #> rmtfit.formula(formula = ms(id, time, status) ~ rx, data = colon_lev) #>  #> Restricted mean winning time by tau = 7.5: #>           State 1 Survival  Overall #> Control 0.2659633 1.130967 1.396930 #> Lev+5FU 0.6120146 1.750924 2.362938 #>  #> Restricted mean time in favor of group "Lev+5FU" by time tau = 7.5: #>          Estimate  Std.Err Z value  Pr(>|z|)     #> State 1  0.346051 0.072066  4.8018 1.572e-06 *** #> Survival 0.619957 0.213610  2.9023  0.003704 **  #> Overall  0.966008 0.252585  3.8245  0.000131 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

previous_headings: AN EXAMPLE WITH A COLON CANCER TRIAL
title: Analysis of multistate hierarchical outcomes by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: Use following code construct bouquet plot plot estimated \mu(\cdot):  left panel, restricted mean survival (dark gray) pre-relapse times (light gray) clearly favor treatment, increasingly follow-continues. right panel, judging lower 95% confidence limit, treatment effect becomes significant 0.05 level soon randomization stays till end study. plot component-specific curves , run
code: # set-up plot parameters oldpar <- par(mfrow = par("mfrow")) par(mfrow=c(1,2))  # Bouquet plot bouquet(obj,main="Bouquet plot",cex.group=0.8, xlab="Restricted mean win/loss time (years)",         ylab="Follow-up time (years)") #cex.group: font size of group labels# # Plot of RMT in favor of treatment over time plot(obj,conf=TRUE,col='red',conf.col='blue',conf.lty=2, xlab="Follow-up time (years)",         ylab="RMT in favor of treatment (years)",main="Overall") par(oldpar) # set-up plot parameters oldpar <- par(mfrow = par("mfrow")) par(mfrow=c(1,2))  # Plot of component-wise RMT in favor of treatment over time plot(obj,k=2,conf=TRUE,col='red',conf.col='blue',conf.lty=2, xlab="Follow-up time (years)",         ylab="RMT in favor of treatment (years)",main="Survival") plot(obj,k=1,conf=TRUE,col='red',conf.col='blue',conf.lty=2, xlab="Follow-up time (years)",         ylab="RMT in favor of treatment (years)",main="Pre-relapse") par(oldpar)

title: Analysis of composite endpoints of recurrent event and death by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: vignette demonstrates use R-package rmt restricted-mean-time--favor--treatment approach analysis composite outcomes consisting recurrent event death.

title: Analysis of composite endpoints of recurrent event and death by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: Let N(t) denote counting process recurrent event, e.g., repeated hospitalizations, let N_D(t) denote death. composite outcome process defined Y(t)=N(t)+\infty N_D(t). , Y(t) counts number non-fatal event living patient jumps \infty patient dies. Traditional ways combining components include: Time first event: Y^*(t)=\{N(t)+N_D(t)>0\}; Weighted composite event process (Mao Lin, 2016): Y^{**}(t)=N(t)+w_DN_D(t) w_D\geq 1; Compared approaches, Y(t) advantage including events prioritizing death natural, hierarchical way.

title: Analysis of composite endpoints of recurrent event and death by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: Let Y^{()} denote outcome process group (=1 treatment =0 control). estimand interest constructed generalized pairwise comparison framework (Buyse, 2010). Y^{(1)}\perp Y^{(0)}, let \mu(\tau)=E\int_0^\tau \{Y^{(1)}(t)< Y^{(0)}(t)\}{\rm d}t - E\int_0^\tau \{Y^{(1)}(t)> Y^{(0)}(t)\}{\rm d}t, pre-specified follow-time \tau. call \mu(\tau) restricted mean time (RMT) favor treatment interpret average time gained treatment favorable condition. generalizes familiar restricted mean survival time account non-fatal events. fact, can shown \mu(\tau) reduces net restricted mean survival time (Royston & Parmar, 2011) N(t)\equiv 0. details methodology, refer Mao (2021). overall effect size admits component-wise decomposition: \mu(\tau)=\mu_D(\tau)+\mu_H(\tau), \begin{equation}\tag{*} \mu_D(\tau)=E\int_0^\tau \{Y^{(1)}(t)<\infty, Y^{(0)}(t)=\infty\}{\rm d} t- E\int_0^\tau \{Y^{(0)}(t)<\infty, Y^{(0)}(t)=\infty\}{\rm d} t \end{equation} equivalent standard net restricted mean survival time \mu_H(\tau)=E\int_0^\tau \{Y^{(1)}(t)< Y^{(0)}(t)<\infty\}{\rm d}t - E\int_0^\tau \{Y^{(0)}(t)< Y^{(1)}(t)<\infty\}{\rm d}t average time gained treatment fewer non-fatal events among living patients. second component can decomposed \mu_H(\tau)=\sum_{k=1}^K\mu_k(\tau), \begin{equation}\tag{**} \mu_k(\tau)=E\int_0^\tau \{Y^{(1)}(t)<k, Y^{(0)}(t)=k\}{\rm d} t- E\int_0^\tau \{Y^{(0)}(t)<k, Y^{(0)}(t)=k\}{\rm d} t, \end{equation} K maximum number non-fatal event. quantity \mu_k(\tau) can interpreted average time gained treatment experiencing kth non-fatal event among living patients.

title: Analysis of composite endpoints of recurrent event and death by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment

Specifically, need id variable containing unique patient identifiers, time variable containing event times, status variable labeling event type (status=1 non-fatal event, =2 death, =0 censoring), , finally, binary trt variable containing subject-level treatment arm indicators. id, time, status, trt variables data frame data, can use formula form function: Otherwise, can feed vector-valued variables directly function: Note last type option must specified; otherwise input treated multistate rather recurrent event data. returned object obj contains basically information overall component-wise RMTs. extract relevant information particular \tau=tau, use last option Kmax specified, say, l, estimates \mu_k(\tau) k=l,\ldots, K aggregated, .e., \sum_{k=l}^K\mu_k(\tau). Therefore, make inference \mu_H(\tau), use

previous_headings: AN EXAMPLE WITH THE HF-ACTION TRIAL
title: Analysis of composite endpoints of recurrent event and death by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: total two thousand heart failure patients across USA, Canada, France participated Heart Failure: Controlled Trial Investigating Outcomes Exercise Training 2003–2007 (O’Connor et al., 2009). primary objective trial evaluate effect adding exercise training usual patient care composite endpoint -cause hospitalization death. consider subgroup 426 non-ischemic patients baseline cardio-pulmonary exercise test less equal nine minutes. subgroup, 205 patients randomly assigned receive exercise training addition usual care 221 receive usual care alone. median follow-time 28 months, death rates exercise training usual care groups 18% 26%, average numbers recurrent hospitalizations per patient 2.2 2.6, respectively. maximum number hospitalizations per patient K=26. dataset hfaction contained rmt package can loaded dataset already format suitable rmtfit() (status= 1 hospitalization = 2 death).

previous_headings: AN EXAMPLE WITH THE HF-ACTION TRIAL
title: Analysis of composite endpoints of recurrent event and death by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: first fit data output, conclude , 3.5 years, combined treatment average gains patient \mu(\tau)=0.36 extra year favorable state compared control. total effect size comprises additional \mu_D(\tau)=0.20 year survival time \mu_H(\tau)=0.36-0.20=0.16 year fewer hospitalizations among living. latter component mainly driven prolonging time third hospitalization. matrix containing inferential results can obtained summary(obj,tau=3.5,Kmax=4)$tab. obtain inferential result \mu_H(\tau) whole, run

previous_headings: AN EXAMPLE WITH THE HF-ACTION TRIAL
title: Analysis of composite endpoints of recurrent event and death by the restricted mean time in favor of treatment
text: Use following code construct bouquet plot plot estimated \mu(\cdot):  bouquet plot, four bands different shades gray, darkest lightest, correspond survival, 4+ hospitalizations, 3 hospitalization, 2 hospitalizations, 1 hospitalization, respectively. can see restricted mean survival time clearly favor exercise training. restricted mean win times second third hospitalizations also visibly greater treatment group. 95% confidence limits \mu(\tau) right panel suggests overall treatment effect becomes significant 0.05 level approximately 1 year follow-stays till end study.
code: # set-up plot parameters oldpar <- par(mfrow = par("mfrow")) par(mfrow=c(1,2))  # Bouquet plot bouquet(obj,Kmax=4,main="Bouquet plot",cex.group=0.8, xlab="Restricted mean win/loss time (years)",          ylab="Follow-up time (years)", cex.main=0.8) #cex.group: font size of group labels# # Plot of RMT in favor of treatment over time plot(obj,conf=TRUE,col='red',conf.col='blue',conf.lty=2, xlab="Follow-up time (years)",         ylab="RMT in favor of treatment (years)",main="Exercise training vs usual care",      cex.main=0.8) par(oldpar)

what: Restricted Mean Time in Favor of Treatment
title: Restricted Mean Time in Favor of Treatment
text: rmt package implements restricted mean time favor (RMT-) treatment approach hierarchical composite endpoints (Mao 2022). user-specified restriction times, one can estimate make inference effect size well components (Mao Wang 2023) . Sample size calculation routines also available (Mao 2023b, 2023a).

Kmax positive integer; specified, stage-wise estimates Kmax\(,\ldots,K\) aggregated. xlim x limits plot. ylim y limits plot. xlab label x axis, defaults description x. ylab label y axis, defaults description x. group.label TRUE, group labels appear two sides plot. cex.group Font size group labels group.label=TRUE. ... arguments can passed underlying plot method.

what: A dataset from a landmark colon cancer trial — colon_lev
title: A dataset from a landmark colon cancer trial — colon_lev
text: landmark colon cancer trial efficacy levamisole fluorouracil reported Moertel et al. (1990). trial recruited 929 patients stage C disease randomly assigned levamisole treatment alone, levamisole combined fluorouracil, control. dataset restricted comparison combined treatment control groups, consisting 304 314 patients, respectively.

title: A dataset from a landmark colon cancer trial — colon_lev
A dataset from a landmark colon cancer trial — colon_lev
text: data frame 915 rows 6 variables: id Unique patient ID. time Event time (years). status Event type; 1 = cancer relapse, 2 = death. rx "Lev+5FU" = combined treatment, "Control" = control. age Patient age (years) randomization. sex 0 = female, 1 = male.

title: A dataset from a landmark colon cancer trial — colon_lev
text: MOERTEL, C. G., FLEMING, T. R., MACDONALD, J. S., HALLER, D. G., LAURIE, J. ., GOODMAN, P. J., UNGERLEIDER, J. S., EMERSON, W. ., TORMEY, D. C., GLICK, J. H. et al. (1990). Levamisole fluorouracil  adjuvant therapy resected colon carcinoma. New Engl. J. Med. 322, 352–358.

what: A dataset from the HF-ACTION trial — hfaction
title: A dataset from the HF-ACTION trial — hfaction
text: two thousand heart failure patients across USA, Canada, France participated Heart Failure: Controlled Trial Investigating Outcomes Exercise Training (HF-ACTION) 2003–2007 (O'Connor et al., 2009). primary objective trial evaluate effect adding exercise training usual patient care composite endpoint -cause hospitalization  death. dataset contains subgroup 426 non-ischemic patients baseline cardio-pulmonary exercise test less equal nine minutes.

title: A dataset from the HF-ACTION trial — hfaction
A dataset from the HF-ACTION trial — hfaction
text: data frame 1,448 rows 5 variables: patid Unique patient ID. time Event time (years). status Event type; 1 = hospitalization, 2 = death. trt_ab 1 = exercise training, 0 = usual care. age60 1 = 60 years older, 0 = otherwise.

title: A dataset from the HF-ACTION trial — hfaction
text: O'CONNOR, C. M., WHELLAN, D. J., LEE, K. L., KETEYIAN, S. J.,  COOPER, L. S., ELLIS, S. J., LEIFER, E. S., KRAUS, W. E., KITZMAN, D. W., BLUMENTHAL, J. . et al. (2009). Efficacy safety exercise training  patients chronic heart failure: Hf-action randomized controlled trial.  J. . Med. Assoc. 301, 1439–1450.

code: # load the colon cancer trial data library(rmt) head(colon_lev) #>   id      time status      rx sex age #> 1  1 2.6502396      1 Lev+5FU   1  43 #> 2  1 4.1642710      2 Lev+5FU   1  43 #> 3  2 8.4517454      0 Lev+5FU   1  63 #> 4  3 1.4839151      1 Control   0  71 #> 5  3 2.6365503      2 Control   0  71 #> 6  4 0.6707734      1 Lev+5FU   0  66 # fit the data obj=rmtfit(ms(id,time,status)~rx,data=colon_lev) # plot overal effect mu(tau) plot(obj)  # set-up plot parameters oldpar <- par(mfrow = par("mfrow")) par(mfrow=c(1,2)) # Plot of component-wise RMT in favor of treatment over time plot(obj,k=2,conf=TRUE,col='red',conf.col='blue', xlab="Follow-up time (years)",     ylab="RMT in favor of treatment (years)",main="Survival") plot(obj,k=1,conf=TRUE,col='red',conf.col='blue', xlab="Follow-up time (years)",     ylab="RMT in favor of treatment (years)",main="Pre-relapse")  par(oldpar)

what: Estimate restricted mean times in favor of treatment — rmtfit
title: Estimate restricted mean times in favor of treatment — rmtfit
text: Estimate make inference overall component-wise restricted mean times favor treatment.

title: Estimate restricted mean times in favor of treatment — rmtfit
code: rmtfit(...)  # Default S3 method rmtfit(id, time, status, trt, type = "multistate", ...)  # S3 method for class 'formula' rmtfit(formula, data, ...)

title: Estimate restricted mean times in favor of treatment — rmtfit
text: ... arguments. id vector id variable. time vector follow-times. status type="multistate", k = entering state \(k\) (\(K+1\) represents death) 0 = censoring; type="recurrent", 1 = recurrent event, 2 = death, 0 = censoring; trt vector binary variable treatment group. type "multistate" = multistate data; "recurrent" = recurrent event data. formula formula object. multistate data, use ms(id,time,status)~trt; recurrent event data, use rec(id,time,status)~trt. data data frame, contains variables names formula.

title: Estimate restricted mean times in favor of treatment — rmtfit
text: object class rmtfit. See rmtfit.object details.

title: Estimate restricted mean times in favor of treatment — rmtfit
text: rmtfit(default): Default rmtfit(formula): Formula

title: Estimate restricted mean times in favor of treatment — rmtfit
code: ####################### # Multistate outcome  # ####################### # load the colon cancer trial data library(rmt) head(colon_lev) #>   id      time status      rx sex age #> 1  1 2.6502396      1 Lev+5FU   1  43 #> 2  1 4.1642710      2 Lev+5FU   1  43 #> 3  2 8.4517454      0 Lev+5FU   1  63 #> 4  3 1.4839151      1 Control   0  71 #> 5  3 2.6365503      2 Control   0  71 #> 6  4 0.6707734      1 Lev+5FU   0  66 # fit the data obj=rmtfit(ms(id,time,status)~rx,data=colon_lev) # print the event numbers by group obj #> Call: #> rmtfit.formula(formula = ms(id, time, status) ~ rx, data = colon_lev) #>  #>           N State 1 Death Med follow-up time #> Control 315     177   168           5.081451 #> Lev+5FU 304     119   123           5.749487 # summarize the inference results for tau=7.5 years summary(obj,tau=7.5) #> Call: #> rmtfit.formula(formula = ms(id, time, status) ~ rx, data = colon_lev) #>  #> Restricted mean winning time by tau = 7.5: #>           State 1 Survival  Overall #> Control 0.2659633 1.130967 1.396930 #> Lev+5FU 0.6120146 1.750924 2.362938 #>  #> Restricted mean time in favor of group "Lev+5FU" by time tau = 7.5: #>          Estimate  Std.Err Z value  Pr(>|z|)     #> State 1  0.346051 0.072066  4.8018 1.572e-06 *** #> Survival 0.619957 0.213610  2.9023  0.003704 **  #> Overall  0.966008 0.252585  3.8245  0.000131 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1  ############################ # Recurrent event outcome  # ############################ # load the HF-ACTION trial data library(rmt) head(hfaction) #>        patid       time status trt_ab age60 #> 1 HFACT00001 0.60506502      1      0     1 #> 2 HFACT00001 1.04859685      0      0     1 #> 3 HFACT00002 0.06297057      1      0     1 #> 4 HFACT00002 0.35865845      1      0     1 #> 5 HFACT00002 0.39698836      1      0     1 #> 6 HFACT00002 3.83299110      0      0     1 # fit the data obj=rmtfit(rec(patid,time,status)~trt_ab,data=hfaction) # print the event numbers by group obj #> Call: #> rmtfit.formula(formula = rec(patid, time, status) ~ trt_ab, data = hfaction) #>  #>     N Event 1 Event 2 Event 3 Event 4 Event 5 Event 6 Event 7 Event 8 Event 9 #> 0 221     170     117      86      56      33      23      15      13      13 #> 1 205     145      89      55      43      32      21      15      11       7 #>   Event 10 Event 11 Event 12 Event 13 Event 14 Event 15 Event 16 Event 17 #> 0       11        7        6        6        5        3        2        2 #> 1        5        4        3        2        2        2        2        2 #>   Event 18 Event 19 Event 20 Event 21 Event 22 Event 23 Event 24 Event 25 #> 0        2        1        0        0        0        0        0        0 #> 1        2        2        1        1        1        1        1        1 #>   Event 26 Death Med follow-up time #> 0        0    57           2.390144 #> 1        1    36           2.302533 # summarize the inference results for tau=3.5 years summary(obj,tau=3.5,Kmax=4) # aggregating results for recurrent-event #> Call: #> rmtfit.formula(formula = rec(patid, time, status) ~ trt_ab, data = hfaction) #>  #> Restricted mean winning time by tau = 3.5: #>     Event 1   Event 2    Event 3    Event 4    Event 5    Event 6    Event 7 #> 0 0.2461459 0.1797341 0.07400189 0.05705096 0.06778913 0.03229824 0.02901336 #> 1 0.2606647 0.2246581 0.18911776 0.07928876 0.05043218 0.04036515 0.01434557 #>      Event 8    Event 9    Event 10    Event 11    Event 12     Event 13 #> 0 0.02467620 0.01351584 0.007900133 0.001056981 0.007932054 0.0006445581 #> 1 0.01169075 0.01232759 0.009301100 0.004563094 0.001627585 0.0024747931 #>       Event 14     Event 15     Event 16     Event 17     Event 18     Event 19 #> 0 0.0007787642 0.0003834044 0.0003137311 0.0001010352 0.0001123888 0.0004848228 #> 1 0.0077805017 0.0019915287 0.0007116988 0.0003040931 0.0003580146 0.0001079202 #>       Event 20     Event 21     Event 22     Event 23    Event 24     Event 25 #> 0 0.0001781611 0.0007311137 0.0003162343 0.0005731831 0.001192464 0.0002290646 #> 1 0.0000000000 0.0000000000 0.0000000000 0.0000000000 0.000000000 0.0000000000 #>      Event 26  Survival  Overall #> 0 0.004352256 0.2967478 1.048254 #> 1 0.000000000 0.4958881 1.407999 #>  #> Restricted mean time in favor of group "1" by time tau = 3.5: #>           Estimate   Std.Err Z value Pr(>|z|)    #> Event 1   0.014519  0.047535  0.3054 0.760034    #> Event 2   0.044924  0.045661  0.9839 0.325185    #> Event 3   0.115116  0.035992  3.1984 0.001382 ** #> Event 4+ -0.013954  0.049358 -0.2827 0.777403    #> Survival  0.199140  0.093300  2.1344 0.032810 *  #> Overall   0.359745  0.154062  2.3351 0.019540 *  #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 # text: t vector follow-times \(\tau\). mu matrix \(K+2\) rows; \(k\)th row \((k=1,\ldots, K)\) \(\mu_k(\tau)\), restricted mean time favor treatment \(k\)th state (recurrent event); \((K+1)\)th row net restricted mean survival time; last row overal effect \(\mu(\tau)\). var matrix \(K+2\) rows containing variance estimates mu. mu10, mu01 Matrices \(K+1\) rows; \(k\)th row \((k=1,\ldots, K)\) restricted mean win (mu10) loss (mu01) times treatment \(k\)th state (recurrent event); \((K+1)\)th row survival time. ...
